conclusion: The capacitor has two plates separated by a distance d, with a metal plate of thickness l on the lower plate and a charged particle P stationary above it.
The electric field E between the plates of a parallel-plate capacitor is given by E = V/d.
The metal plate reduces the effective distance between the plates to d - l, so the electric field above the metal plate is E_initial = V/(d - l).
The force on the charged particle due to the electric field is F = qE_initial.
Initially, the particle is stationary, so the electric force balances the gravitational force: qE_initial = mg.
When the metal plate is removed, the effective distance between the plates returns to d, and the new electric field is E_new = V/d.
The new force on the particle is F_new = qE_new = q(V/d).
The net force on the particle after removing the metal plate is F_net = F_new - mg = q(V/d) - mg.
Using the initial equilibrium condition q(V/(d - l)) = mg, express qV as mg(d - l).
Substitute qV into the net force equation: F_net = mg(d - l)/d - mg = -mg(l/d).
The acceleration a of the particle is given by a = F_net/m = -g(l/d).
The acceleration of the particle P when the metal plate is removed is a = -g(l/d).
